Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: PEC: A Data-Centric Architecture for Pervasive Edge Computing in Heterogeneous Extensible Distributed Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to develop a novel data-centric architecture and accompanying protocols/algorithms to enable peer based data discovery, dissemination and processing for future mobile sensing applications among heterogeneous edge devices (e.g., smartphones, tablets) without relying on any centralized backend as is currently done.

The project uses named data to enable direct data sharing and processing among vast numbers of heterogeneous edge devices. The research systematically investigates: 1) Naming structures and constructs suitable for precise reference and characterization of various kinds of data; 2) Data discovery and name matching mechanisms for devices to find what data are available and acquire desired ones; 3) Transparent processing that derives and extracts new data from raw sensing samples. The project combines architecture, protocol and algorithm design, optimization, testbed implementations and software simulations for a full-scale study on the above issues.

This research will enable a future generation of mobile sensing applications no longer requiring a centralized backend, thus completely eliminating the associated monetary, manpower costs, and dependence on the availability and performance of Internet connectivity. The PIs are developing a new graduate course, training graduate students, and reaching out to undergraduate and high school students to build futuristic applications. Joint explorations with leading research and development organizations are conducted to apply the research results. The publications, software and experimental data are shared with the community to foster further research on this architecture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to design, develop and evaluate a novel data-centric architecture and accompanying protocols to support a pervasive edge computing paradigm in large-scale extensible distributed systems composed of heterogeneous edge devices. Modern edge devices, exemplified by smartphones and tablets, now possess various sensing, computing and communication capabilities. They have created an explosion of applications that gather, process and distribute sensing data for transportation, environment, infrastructure, fitness and health. Despite great successes, these applications usually rely on a centralized backend for data sharing and processing, with edge devices communicating only with the backend. Thus their functioning is critically dependent on and vulnerable to the performance, cost and availability of Internet connectivity, and monetary resources, human efforts to maintain the backend. This research seeks to create a radically different paradigm where heterogeneous, pervasively distributed edge devices collectively acquire, process and exchange data in a systematic and scalable fashion, thus completely eliminating such dependency and vulnerability. The research is inspired by the observation that while radios on modern edge devices can communicate directly with each other, the endpoint based communication primitives they use are fundamentally inadequate means to the precise acquisition, flexible processing and agile dissemination of myriad data needed in peer-based data exchange where extreme dynamism, heterogeneity and uncertainty are the norm. Therefore a change of paradigm is necessary in order to take advantage of the pervasive, connected edge devices without requiring the global Internet access.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

This research takes a ?data-centric? approach and builds on top of the emerging Named Data Networking (NDN) architecture. In NDN, ?named data? become first-class citizen and the purpose of the network is to facilitate data discovery, retrieval, and authentication, rather than connecting hosts. This allows applications to fulfill their goals of managing the lifecycles of data without relying reaching particular backend servers. We also take an application-driven approach, where the development of network mechanisms are driven by applications needs and evaluated from the applications? point of view.

 

Realizing that there is a gap between the rich semantics of general applications and the basic Interest/Data exchange of NDN network, we first design a middleware-based architecture that bridges this gap and brings applications and NDN together. This middleware contains interfaces for application queries/replies and for NDN Interest/Data, and necessary name conversion between them. It supports data discovery within the network reach, name decomposition if a query needs to be broken down to finer-grained Interests in the middle of the network, and data fusion when results need to be combined. We then design a number of network mechanisms within this architecture to improve performance and usability. One is a self-learning mechanism that can discovery data without any configuration or routing protocols, another is OpenCache, which can make use of off-path cache to improve performance. Finally we put the architecture in real use scenarios to make mobile devices be able to retrieve emails and group chat within local network with no Internet connectivity. The resulting app, called MailSync, demonstrates that a middleware can be deployed to enable existing applications communicate ?off-the-grid? over NDN without modification. The experience from these works and the building blocks developed will pave the way to future development of the next-generation edge-device-based applications.

 

Broader Impacts

 

This project has two major broader impacts. First, the architecture and mechanisms developed from the project will enable a new generation of applications no longer requiring a centralized backend and the associated monetary, manpower costs, or dependent on the availability and performance of Internet connectivity. Second, the project has contributed to teaching and workforce development by training a number of graduate and undergraduate students in research skills and helping their career development. The content of the research has also been used to improve both graduate and undergraduate courses.
